[h1]Wait for DLC or Buy On Sale[/h1]
Frost Punk 2 has several significant issues and it is hard for me to recommend the game to anyone who is a major fan of Frost Punk 1.  Overall the game is not bad, and many aspects are actually very good but there are several major pain points the drag the current state of the game down.

[b]Minor contextual spoilers ahead, you have been warned[/b]

[h2]Tutorials (or lack thereof)[/h2]
The story starts with what seems to be the intended tutorial but really the chapter is barely able to be called a tutorial.  This is mainly because the opening chapter only covers a small fraction of the game with the rest of the tutorial tucked away in a purely text/image tutorial window.  This tutorial documentation is actually good and does a decent job of explaining the remaining aspects of the game, but it is so detached from the rest of the game that I would be surprised if most players open it, as is up to the player to break out of the immersion of the game to read the tutorial documentation.  It is completely breaking of the game, and really a failure on 11-bit's part to not integrate the tutorial better.  The sad part is, we known they can integrate a tutorial into the natural flow of the game as that is how Frost Punk 1 worked.  Small pop-ups and events that happen in Frost Punk 1 guide the player and introduce new mechanics in a natural and well defined way, but sadly Frost Punk 2 forgoes all of this, instead condemning the player to break their immersion and spent time reading the tutorial instead of playing the game.

[h2]UI (Why is Everything White?)[/h2]
For a game that is set on largely white background, with largely white features, it is strange that the UI is also largely white or grey.  Generally, it is hard to read the, otherwise very gorgeous and well done UI, because everything just tends to blend into each other.  [spoiler]For instance, frost breaking, the act of breaking up the snow/ice so you can build there, requires the users to select tiles that are marked bright white, from tiles that either grey (already broken) or not as bright white (not accessible tiles).[/spoiler]  I generally am not sure how a visually impaired person is able to play this game as so many elements of the UI just blend in with each other.

The game does come with a dark mode, but the developers decided to throw a warning in that turning on dark mode will result in a lost of UI look and feel.  I guess the devs are trying to warn that dark mode is not the intended way to play, but if that is truly the case then maybe the devs should re-evaluate why they felt the need to include dark mode in the first place.  Additionally, for some reason dark mode does degrade some of the few colored elements in the UI, to monotone colors, which just seems completely unnecessary.  

[h2]Performance (Another New Game, Another Example of Terrible Launch Performance)[/h2]
The game tricks the user into thinking that the game will perform well as the initial half of a play through tends to play very well.  Movement is fluid, clicks are responsive, and saves are not disruptive, but somewhere around the half way point everything starts to fall apart.  

Take saving, the game defaults to auto-saving at regular intervals and, importantly, the game is completely frozen while a save is happening.  At first, this minor inconvenience as the auto-save will freeze the game for a second and is generally not an issue, but as the city grows the time it takes to save also grows.  This ultimately culminates in 30+ second long save times when in the late game (all saves are to SSDs).  This is exasperated by the auto-save feature which makes it very frustrating to be dealing with a crisis in the game and then suddenly everything stops, you can't click on anything, you can't do anything, but look at the "<saving...>" window and wait, and wait, and wait....  The save performance completely breaks the immersion, and I ultimately thought about turning off auto-saves because it was so disruptive, but doing so would have made the random crashes much more painful.

What would a game launch be without random, game breaking, crashes, and Frost Punk 2 has them in spades.  I will not go into all the issues the Mac community is having as I do not play on a Mac, but they are many and loud on the discord.  No, instead I will focus on my, and my partners, Windows play through.  There appears to be an issues with the game crashing when playing at max speed, and while I did not encounter many crashes, my partner did and they where to the point that they needed to save frequently (remember the save issue, yea, it is even worst when combined with the crashes).  The only main difference between our two devices, I have an Intel CPU, and my partner has an AMD CPU, so maybe there is an issue with AMD CPUs but I do not know for certain.  All I can say is that the same is completely unstable and you are basically forced to play with auto-immersion-breaking-saving on. 

The bright side, 11-bit has been working on trying to resolve these issues and I am hopeful that the issues will be resolved with patches in the coming days/weeks.

[h2]Frost Punk Soul (Where did it go?)[/h2]
All of the above issues with the game can be resolved with patches and updates over time, but the by far the biggest issue with Frost Punk 2 is the [i]almost[/i] lack of soul.  One of the great things about FP 1 is the decisions a player has to make just in who works where, do the children work in the mines (which they yearn for) or does it fall to an automaton?  These kinda of intimate interactions are completely missing from the game, instead [spoiler]districts pull from a generic pool of workers, are they children? Maybe.  They could also be automatons or the elderly, who knows![/spoiler]  These interactions, and others, are what made FP 1 so great and also so hard, but achievable.  I have hard a lot of players say that FP 2 is so much harder than FP 1 ever was, but I do not feel like that difficulty is truly because the game is harder.  Instead, the game generally feels harder not because it is harder, but because the player has significantly less tools to deal with any given crisis.  [spoiler]Instead, the player is left to building districts and sending out exploration teams, while occasionally throwing some stubborn party a gift/punishment to keep them from trying to tear everything down.[/spoiler]  Ultimately, the only time I felt truly moved or emotional was the very end of the story, which presents the player with an almost deep philosophical dive into the what is means to create a "utopia".   This is really the heart of FP 2 issues, the new scale of the game means that the intimate details that made FP 1 great are completely lost, and I am not sure there is a good way that can be fixed without some major redesigns.

[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]
Generally, FP 2 is a good and unique city builder game, the additional content truly pushes the boundaries and fulfills some wishes of FP 1. Sadly FP 2 is not the gritty [b]survival[/b] city builder that FP 1, and that is why I have a hard time recommending this game anyone other than a purely city builder fan.  I really hope that 11-bit can find away to bring back in some the moral and heart felt soul of FP 1, but until then, FP 2 feel just like a shell of the greatness that is FP 1.

Frostpunk 2 is not trying to be Frostpunk 1; this is not Frostpunk 1.5. This is Frostpunk 2; a proper sequel.

You'll see a lot of reviews on here complaining that this diverted too much from what made Frostpunk great and you'll see a lot of people saying that the changes made here go in the wrong direction. I disagree. This game is still VERY Frostpunk: the game throws you into the frostland and you must keep the generator running and supplies coming all while the people of your city bicker and complain about the direction you take the city. The political side of Frostpunk 2 is vastly expanded on; passing laws and pleasing factions are far more important this time around. It is a core fundamental aspect of this sequel to delve into the political landscape of your city and carefully pick and choose which laws are passed and which factions to support. The final chapter of the campaign was so intense I literally can't remember a time where a game like this got me to that level of engagement and immersion. 

You'll learn A LOT about how to progress more successfully with each new city you make, whether it be trying the campaign on harder difficulties or picking different maps in the Utopia mode. I've now gone through three runs each with varying levels of success: the first one being marginally successful just enough to get by, the second one being vastly successful ensuring that my city stands long after I die, and the third crumbling from existence because of my inability to rule it properly. This game's insistence on forcing you to learn is extremely engaging and it really is the key reason why I can see myself putting dozens of more hours into this. 

Exploring the frostland and building resource outposts, surviving the blizzards, and ensuring every faction has their voice heard all make for a gameplay system that constantly keeps you engaged and really never gives you a dull moment. Each new run on a new map presents new challenges and new opportunities. 

While many will be disappointed that this isn't the same as Frostpunk 1, I think the evolution made in this entry still makes it extremely engaging and I have high hopes for the future of this franchise.

First review on Steam.

Pros:
- Stunning scenes with adaptive lighting, bloom, focus blur, and filters. Combine it with camera work and it's a marvel of game visuals.
- Lots of customization options.
- Calming BGM + satisfying ASMR SFX. Even as you hover over colors to pick, there are singular xylophone sounds playing with each option.
- Highly adaptive procedural adaptations as well as decorative nuances. Bird nests popping up in roof creases and sheeps floating with umbrellas being my cherries-on-top.
- No visible limiting grid, or as they'd say, 'gridless.'
- Very low price compared to what it offers.
- Demo save transfers well into the full game.

Some introductory tutorials in sandbox games can be invasive and interrupting a smooth gameplay, especially if you skip it or will miss something major if you do. This game isn't about that.

You're welcome to explore on your own what this droplet button does, what dragging this wall sideways will do, what will happen if you choose to put three windows together, etc. With the vast customization and options, I find that in my first 3 hours of playing, I keep learning new things non-stop.

You're not spoon-fed with rules, told to run tasks, follow a story, or even taught how to do things - instead, you adapt on your own, just like how the game adapts to what little changes you do. You make the glade feel like home, and the game gladly returns the favor, creating a flourishing mutualistic ecosystem and the humbling sandbox experience that the game is.

Bugs found:
- Certain bugs for item positioning/adaptation. Ex: ivy remains floating in the air from removed/shrunk buildings.
- Camera bugs. Ex: camera got stuck in one zoomed angle, can still move but always returns to the stuck angle. Restarting the game resets it and no progress were lost.

Suggestions for developers to add:

- Options to group objects together
- Controls to lock & unlock objects from moving or changing
- Controls to copy, cut, and paste objects/group of objects
- Options to pick and drop color, also to color multiple objects at once
- Options to enable interactive humans/humanoid characters to inhabit or explore glades the way wild animals do
- Additional water/terrain option: automatic square or circular shape in addition to the manual drawing option
- Additional delete option: wipe the entire scene out of trees, buildings, etc with just one click
- Options to manually add furniture/items for decor aside from automatic procedural adaptations
- Options to generate bridges with different styles (as opposed to people manually making it with building tricks)
- Options to generate stairs with different styles (as opposed to people also manually making it with building tricks)
- Options to generate moving water like rivers or waterfalls.
- Options to generate more terrain items like stones, logs, stumps, as well as more variation of flowers and plants.
- Additional options to change the weather, i.e cloudy, raining, etc
- And ofc more choice for scenes & building styles, perhaps some that captures dark gothic aesthetic or eastern/oriental style designs if that already hasn't been in development (highly suspect it has)

As a hardcore ROTK fan, this is probably one of the top three worse ROTK games. 

The battle mechanics are way worse. They did some weird thing where you can only give an order or series of orders during your turn that plays out in the battle phase. Sounds ok at first, but you'll soon find units sitting around and waiting after destroying an enemy unit while 4 hexes away another enemy army is beating up your ally. It's all based around the AI settings that you put forth, but the AI is too simplistic to be intuitive, or even show some semblance of intelligence.

You'll find everything is based around AI. All you do as a ruler is use excel with a poor UI. Duels? Only watching as two dudes just hit each other. Debates? What's that? Marriage/sworn brothers system, 10,000g for a slight buff in battle and loyalty.  Don't even get me started on their new event system.

There's not room for roleplay or to immerse yourself. Just play ROTK 8, 10, or 11, they are just more in depth and provide more. 

There is no desire for me to develop my generals. They provide you tons of skills to train your generals. But it's just a chore and takes so much time for no benefit. Maybe if I had some sort of attachment to my generals in any shape or form, I would. But it's all just stats.

For Christ's sake, ROTK4 had more depth in it and that was a SNES game on 16 bits. I don't know who they are trying to entertain with this game.

review_text:
Inability to Promote Officers During Battle: It's frustrating that we can't promote officers while they're in battle. We're forced to wait until everyone is back at base before promoting them.

Difficulty Employing Characters Like Guan Yu, Zhang Fei, and Cai Yan: Despite numerous attempts, we're unable to employ characters like Guan Yu, Zhang Fei, and Cai Yan. We keep receiving alerts that they're unemployed, yet they continue to reject our offers.

Uninteresting Battle Duels: The battle duels lack excitement. I remember a version of ROTK where duels were engaging, with buttons to press for counters and other actions. Incorporating such features would greatly enhance the gameplay experience.

Lackluster Area/City Government Mechanics: The mechanics for managing area and city governments are dull. It simply involves assigning an officer and then repeatedly sending idle officers out for employment until orders are depleted.

Stagnant Background Music (BGM): The BGM remains unchanged from many versions ago, which contributes to a feeling of stagnation in the game's overall experience.

Overall, the game feels more like a remastered version of an older ROTK installment rather than a significant improvement. Despite advancements in graphics, fundamental gameplay elements have seen little to no enhancement over the years.

I'll break this down simply.
The most realistic parts of this game and series as a whole:
- The look of the aircraft, ordinance, and effects.
- Some of the atmospheric effects: weather, vector trails, vapour, albeit no contrails above FL300ish as of yet.
- The diversity in aircraft types.
- The air battle management dialogue and presentation, which is fairly well depicted for a video game. It's clear that they consulted with real Tactical Air Traffic controllers on some level.
- The depiction of Tactical Data Link in a practical sense, especially with regard to ID classification.
- Playtime WRT length of missions.
- Plot points such as electronic warfare, drones, AI.
The least realistic parts:
- Let's be honest, ammunition load-out storage. Ridiculous. But the missions would be 5 minutes long, force you to land and take off repeatedly, or only have a couple land targets and a single enemy fighter group otherwise.
- Mechanics of fighter jet flight. Totally ridiculous. But fun and arcade-esque.
- Mechanics of air weapon flight. Ridiculous to keep up with the aircraft they are targeting. Fair enough.
- Fidelity of radar, comms, and link coverage. Not realistic for things to just work perfectly everywhere always. Just a game though.
- Plot points such as gigantic aircraft carriers, rail guns, and space elevators. Too expensive in the real world to ever make sense. Alluring as a fantasy depiction for sure.
- Pilot response to the ridiculous acceleration/deceleration and +/-G forces. That is not at all depicted in the series during gameplay. However it is mentioned in cutscenes.
- Supersonic depiction, something that I have only seen accurately depicted in flight simulator.
- It would be cool to have an depiction of Mach, IAS, and TAS if not for pure effect.
- It would be cool to have the cockpit depict information completely much like the VR presentation.

If I missed anything... well you'll see. I highly recommend any game in this series. This is the best seller for a reason but the story is a little more compelling in AC4 and its subsequent releases. Hopefully one day we will get remakes and remasters because these games have a lot of replayability and the older titles are kind of forgotten given their generation. The developers don't have to improve too much to keep fans happy, aside from a better multiplayer experience and some minor touch-ups, such as inaccurate sound effects and a storyline that isn't really very sad.
